text: uh hi everyone here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new glass Beach record the
first glass beach album this thing is
out now via run for cover records and
admittedly I am kind of late to the
party
whoa party I put the record off again
and again and again as I was covering
other stuff throughout the year and
maybe I shouldn't have but I was being
constantly reminded by fans that this
album was something special and even
though I didn't review the record up
until now I had listened to it here and
there throughout the year and I was
pretty impressed initially with the
diverse array of influences going into
the tracklist this LP not only serves up
a pretty rowdy mix of power pop and emo
but the songs here also incorporate
elements of jazz indie tronic music neo
psyche the chord progression and peppy
pacing of the track bedroom community
sounds like something out of a cutesy
anime theme song with a constantly
shape-shifting tracklist the first glass
beach album is a lot to take in at 15
tracks in one hour not only is there a
lot of stylistic diversity across the
record but also some of the songs on
here kind of intricate complex or a bit
long-winded working in multiple phases
the band really has a drive to produce
these rock songs that are energetic but
also sound like these miniature punky
orchestras and even though the execution
on this thing is wild it's a little
loose the end result is still pretty
grand and exhilarating like the track
neon glow which is a very noisy piece of
power pop elevated by these tight
twinkly melodies that pop in every few
bars or so it's aggressive but also
intricate and kind of fun also the
transition after the halfway point of
the song where we start getting some
jangly sad horn backed instrumentation
and the amazing finale the build-up that
it tops things off with that's a pretty
incredible moment - there's also the
intro track classic Jade eyes which has
a very quiet spotlit vocal and piano
intro that's kind of theatrical it
sounds like a sad sad show tune or like
something that would kick off an epic
rock
operas such as MC ARS Black Parade but
then the gentle synth leads and groovy
bass that the song transitions into
pretty quickly after the intro that
sounds like something that is a little J
pop inspired actually and with the
dreary horn passages that come after
along with the punky finale the track
just gets better and better
meanwhile the song Glass Beach kicks off
like a fiery emo rager
it sounds straight out of the 2000s
vocally it's just letting it all out
emotionally speaking I loved the
filthiest hell drums on this track the
kind of angular geometric synth lines
the melody work on the track it's more
and more skilled as the track progresses
along these extended chord progressions
it's beautiful it's anthemic it's
electrifying these tracks are just a few
examples of the multi-genre impressive
progressive dynamic highlights on most
of this record and given the level of
attention to detail on individual songs
here of course there is a lot of
attention to how all of these songs are
flowing together on the entire album -
for the most part the tracklist on this
thing is sequenced really really well
across the album there are nice
transitions from multi-phased epics to
beaming anthems to ambient palate
cleansers I'd also like to quickly
mention the lyrics on this LP - which
mind you aren't bad but I think that
depends on your point of view just
reading the lyrics aloud out of context
one might classify them as just being
boring annoying emote right I get how
some people might have a cynical
reaction when reading lyrics like but
when we're with all our friends can we
just pretend that no one can hurt us
because hey I love you okay it's so hard
to say that I [ __ ] need you to but I
think the record overall is pretty
self-aware in how over-the-top it is
emotionally and compositionally
especially since on the compositional
end the band goes to such lengths to in
a way overdo it in that sense I think
the vocals fit the album very well
because everything on the record feels
so dramatic and theatrical as if every
song or musical phase of the record is a
different scene of some sort my biggest
issue with this LP aside from a few of
the interludes feeling a little too off
the beat
path a little too unrelated to
everything else going on
not really landing as a result of that
my big biggest issue here is that the
record in my opinion does not really
stick the landing as things start to
turn downward in my opinion around areum
there's something I should say about the
record generally before I get too deep
into this track and that's the vocals in
my opinion are the Achilles heel of the
record maybe one of my least favorite
things about the record yeah they're
kind of grating they are
unapologetically whiny but ultimately
they're not as skilled as everything
else going into the project and to me
that feels a bit off-putting however in
the context of what the band is doing
instrumentally what they are trying to
message to their audience as well the
mix of genres going into this thing 90%
of the time or more the vocals work not
on this track though because glass beach
decides to feed the singing through some
kind of obnoxious vocoder
I really don't know but it makes the
singing truly intolerable to me
especially once it starts getting more
aggressive I just can't stand it it's
excruciating I scramble to skip this
track every time the track soft is okay
I guess but the interstitial tracks here
really don't land when they are
shouldered between songs that are more
core to the record but simultaneously
not all that great which brings me to
Yoshi's Island which is maybe the least
gratifying of the longer songs here at
this point it just feels like the band
is dragging the record out unnecessarily
I mean stylistically it doesn't really
bring all that much to the table outside
of a vaguely tropical vibe coming out of
the chords overall I think the tracklist
would have felt a lot less flabby
without this one orchids though is a
pretty decent closer the Soaring sad and
heavy vocals and instrumentation
presented here feel a lot like Andrew
Jackson jihads knife man the closing
track to that record the big epic finale
not quite as big here by comparison but
still pretty hard-hitting and in
certainly a passionate moment on the
record that ties things up pretty nicely
so
overall there are some interludes here
that are just okay the ending drags on a
little bit there are a few glaringly bad
ideas but for the most part the first
glass beach album is a very good record
and impressive debut that has me excited
to see where the band is going to go
next what they're going to sound like
once they start getting even more
ambitious and start smoothing out some
of the rougher edges that they've
presented here as this thing is easily
one of the most versatile dynamic and
varied incredibly creative records in
the fields of emo and power pop that
I've heard this decade I'm feeling a
strong seven to a light eight on this
one transition have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review
